data.text:
Design exploration for mod management tools for developers and modders has begun.
Development of player-facing mod pages and the game mod catalog browse experience have completed a first-pass implementation using mostly mock data.

This issue has been addressed for all Ubisoft titles going forward, some of our existing catalog has been updated to address this issue. We'll continue to pursue updates to the remaining existing Ubisoft catalog games over time.
New APIs have been designed and implemented for partial order refunds support, which is foundational functionality for supporting price protection.
Hand curated collections supported and being tested.

Browse grid integrated with APIs and tags/sorting parameters.
Evaluating performance and navigation.

Component and data integration undergoing testing.
MVP management tooling delivered.
Daily jobs to calculate the trending products together with "most popular" and "top sellers" have been set up and running.

We've shipped our initial phase of the overlay and The Cycle is our first game to use it for in-app purchasing. 

We'll put up new Trello cards to track additional ongoing efforts to improve the overlay as those efforts become more solidified.

data.text:
Development has been completed for DirectX11. We've provided an in-development version of the overlay with commerce support to a partner for early integration feedback.

Direct9-12, Vulkan, OpenGL, and Metal implementations are actively being explored.

card.desc: Add support for automatically refunding the difference in price for purchases that happen a short time before an offer goes on sale.
card.name: Price Protection

data.text: We’ve completed identifying scenarios and work item of price protection and verified with the stakeholder.

We've completed initial design on the trending algorithm. The analytics team has completed the work to aggregate the required data into a suitable form.

We've agreed on a plan for building a new storefront-centric service.
Catalog integration and presentation of mod discovery bare-bones completed.

Additional catalog integrations completed.

Presentation to show all available offers on product detail pages has started development.

The new bundle detail page is visually complete. Data integration is in development.

card.desc: Support for presenting and selling multiple products with a single offer
card.name: Bundles

data.text: Additional required API integration with our catalog service is in dev review. Filter components have been built, reviewed and are in visual test cycles.

Architecture planning and review is underway.

Completed some individual components and are ready for review in our Storybook.

Scoping for internal tooling has begun.

Further iteration was needed to make the experience better. There were some challenges with backfilling consistent assets for the new aspect ratio image. We're moving forward with using the existing 16:9 image.

Added two new filter options for viewing "All" versus "Installed".

Development on the latest iteration is complete and making its way through another QA cycle.

data.text: We've released our updated tool and documentation to our developer partners.

We're actively starting development on supporting mods in the store! This is a huge feature which will take a long time to build. You won't be seeing proper mods support on the store until 2020, but work is starting now.

old.desc: Ability to host product-specific storefronts full of mods. Enables most mod-centric games to come to Epic Games store.

card.desc: We're adding the support for game modding communities. Players will be able to browse a catalog of player and developer made mods for their games. Players will be able to auto-install mods into games they own, that are managed by the Epic Games launcher or download the files separately for other games.
card.name: Mod Support for Games

card.desc: We're adding an algorithmically-driven trending category to the store.
card.name: Storefront - Trending

card.desc: We're going to break up the discovery experience with hand-curated collections.
card.name: Storefront - Curated Collections

data.text: Detailed design is underway.

card.desc: We're going to break the existing storefront into two different experiences, Discover and Browse. The Browsing experience will allow players to search and filter our full catalog.
card.name: Storefront - Browse

data.text: We've completed detailed design. The development team has started breaking the engineering effort into tasks.

card.desc: We're going to break the existing storefront into two different experiences, Discover and Browse. Discover will be the landing page for the store and focus on helping users find new interesting games.
card.name: Storefront - Discover

card.desc: We're creating an in-game overlay. It'll be a while before it's fully realized but our first feature will be the ability for games to allow players to make purchases using Epic Games payment solutions.
card.name: Epic Games Overlay - Checkout

card.name: Launcher Crashes on Some CPUs
card.desc:
Update: A fix has been shipped.

There is currently a known issue that prevents the Epic Games Launcher from running on a class of processors(CPUs) that support the SHA-NI instruction set.  This includes Intel Apollo Lake CPUs, Intel Ice Lake CPUs, and other CPUs that report SHA-NI in the same way.  

The fix for this issue has made its way into other Epic products and will be making its way to the Epic Games Launcher in the near future.

Until the fix makes it out, a potential workaround to this issue is to set the following environment variable before starting the launcher: set OPENSSL_ia32cap=:~0x20000000
To do this you can create a .bat file with the following inside.  Be sure to change the directory to your Epic Games Launcher install folder and run this bat every time you want to run the store.
  cd C:\Program Files (x86)\Epic Games\Launcher\Portal\Binaries\Win32
  set OPENSSL_ia32cap=:~0x20000000
  EpicGamesLauncher.exe

cards.desc:
**Overview**
The purpose of this board is to provide information about upcoming features and known issues with the Epic Games store.

Listed on this board will be features that are currently in development, as well as major known issues as they come up. 

**Connect with Us**
Visit our social channels to stay updated with the most current information! 
[Store](https://www.epicgames.com/store)
[News](https://www.epicgames.com/store/news)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/EpicGames)
[Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/epicgames)
[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/epicgames/)
[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5Qk8mWBwtMyEj7iQQYRk1A)
cards.name: What can you expect from this board?
Roadmap Disclaimer: Features and timing are subject to change.

cards.desc:
Click on the colored bars to reveal or hide label text!

###Labels Currently In Use

**Features**

*Player Quality of Life* - Features focused on improving the consumer experience within the Epic Games store ecosystem, whether it's related to browsing, purchasing or playing your games! 

*Updates Ongoing* - Features that will continue to be updated to create the best user experience possible.

**Known Issues**

*Investigating* - We are aware of the issue and it is under investigation by our development teams. 
 
*Incoming Fix* - We have identified the cause of the issue and a fix is either being worked or ready to be pushed with the next update.
cards.name: Label Tracking

cards.desc:
Here's some helpful info on how to find and track features that are most important to you! 

[Filter by Feature Type](https://help.trello.com/article/787-filtering-cards-on-a-board)
[Subscribe to a Card](https://help.trello.com/article/799-subscribing-to-cards-lists-and-boards)
cards.name: Trello Tips

cards.desc:
We're aware of an issue where Ubisoft games purchased in the Epic Games store have large install footprints. 

We're working actively with Ubisoft to reduce the installation footprint on users machines.
cards.name: Ubisoft Titles Require Large Installs

cards.desc: We're adding the support for game modding communities. Players will be able to browse a catalog of player and developer made mods for their games. Players will be able to auto-install mods into games they own, that are managed by the Epic Games launcher or download the files separately for other games.
cards.name: Mod Support for Games

cards.desc: The launcher offers the ability to skip sign-in, but we'll now be adding an option to sign-in locally even if you don't have an internet connection.
cards.name: Offline Sign-In

cards.desc: Add the ability for players within the refund policy guidelines to be able to self-serve refunds without having to contact Player Support.
cards.name: Self-Service Refunds

cards.desc: We're adding support for throttling the speed in which the launcher downloads content for installs and updates. The goal of this feature is to provide users who have limited bandwidth the opportunity to perform installs and updates over a longer period of time without consuming all of their bandwidth.
cards.name: Download Throttling

cards.desc: We're adding support for the following currencies to our checkout experience. CAD, AUD, SEK, DKK, NOK
cards.name: Local Currencies - CAD, AUD, SEK, DKK, NOK

cards.desc: Enables the player to create a list of store offerings they want to purchase and be notified when they go on sale.
cards.name: Wishlists

cards.desc: Adding support for critic reviews to store product detail pages
cards.name: Critic Reviews

There is currently a known issue that prevents the Epic Games Launcher from running on a class of processors(CPUs) that support the SHA-NI instruction set.  This includes Intel Apollo Lake CPUs, Intel Ice Lake CPUs, and other CPUs that report SHA-NI in the same way.  

The fix for this issue has made its way into other Epic products and will be making its way to the Epic Games Launcher in the near future.

Until the fix makes it out, a potential workaround to this issue is to set the following environment variable before starting the launcher: set OPENSSL_ia32cap=:~0x20000000
To do this you can create a .bat file with the following inside.  Be sure to change the directory to your Epic Games Launcher install folder and run this bat every time you want to run the store.
  cd C:\Program Files (x86)\Epic Games\Launcher\Portal\Binaries\Win32

cards.name: Launcher Crashes on Some CPUs

cards.desc: We're going to break up the discovery experience with hand-curated collections.
cards.name: Storefront - Curated Collections

cards.desc: We're going to break the existing storefront into two different experiences, Discover and Browse. The Browsing experience will allow players to search and filter our full catalog.
cards.name: Storefront - Browse

cards.desc: We're going to break the existing storefront into two different experiences, Discover and Browse. Discover will be the landing page for the store and focus on helping users find new interesting games.
cards.name: Storefront - Discover

cards.desc: As part of the continued improvement of our library, we'll be updating the visuals for the grid view to better align with the new presentation of the storefront.
cards.name: Library Grid View

cards.desc: Add support for coupons and coupon management to the store
cards.name: Coupons

cards.desc: We're creating an in-game overlay. It'll be a while before it's fully realized but our first feature will be the ability for games to allow players to make purchases using Epic Games payment solutions.
cards.name: Epic Games Overlay - Checkout

cards.desc: Support for presenting and selling multiple products with a single offer
cards.name: Bundles

cards.desc: The game library will be getting a new listview, as well as support for sorting and filtering.
cards.name: Library - ListView

cards.desc: Add support for traditional Chinese to the core store experience
cards.name: Traditional Chinese Support

cards.desc: Adds the ability for a player to see how much time they've spent playing each title in their library.
cards.name: Player Play Time Tracking

cards.desc: Enable third-party games to take advantage of the Epic optimized delta solution that have made Fortnite patches much smaller on PC.
cards.name: Improved Patch Sizes

cards.desc:
Enable better product details page by putting more information "above the fold" on pages. Give developers more options in presenting their game to players.

Enable better presentation of games with large numbers of DLC and add-ons (e.g.  editions, expansions, season passes) and different game states (alpha, beta, etc).

**Update:** We are working on the final polish. Check back for exact timing.
cards.name: Store Page Redesign

cards.desc: Infrastructure for the store to host videos natively. This protects users data privacy from other services scarping data. Also allows for a more curated and less obtrusive browsing experience (i.e. less end of video spam).
cards.name: Store Video Hosting

cards.desc: Working with Humble Bundle to integrate non-key-based purchase fulfillment i.e. no more copy/pasting codes around.
cards.name: Humble Bundle Integration

cards.desc:
Support for automatic backup of game save data.

**Update:** We've shipped the V1 implementation of cloud saves. We'll let you know when it’s available across titles that support this feature.
cards.name: Cloud Saves

cards.desc:
Streamlining the skip sign-in experience to enable players to get into their offline games faster.

**Update:** We've shipped changes to improve your offline launcher experience.
cards.name: Improvements to Offline Mode

cards.desc: Adding local currency support for Brazilian Real.
cards.name: Brazilian Currency Support

cards.desc:
**Target:** April 2019

Improved install management backend for the launcher. Will increase / speed up start-up and reduce memory usage. Also paves the way for many new library management features in future.
cards.name: Install Management "Under the Hood" Overhaul

cards.desc: Support for downloadable content
cards.name: Improved DLC Support - Multi SKU

cards.desc: Improves existing search functionality by adding support for genres and tags.
cards.name: Search by Genre and Tag

cards.desc: Improved protection from purchasing add-ons when you don't have the core game.
cards.name: Add-on Purchase Checks

cards.desc: Add Arabic to supported language list for store.
cards.name: Arabic Store Translation

cards.desc: Support the release of store titles in Korea, including local ratings and currently live free titles.
cards.name: Korea Game Releases

cards.desc:
**Target:** March 2019
Allow players to quickly search our store for a particular title by name.
cards.name: Store Search

cards.desc: Players will get notifications when one of the featured, temporarily free games is released on the store every two weeks. These can be disabled in launcher settings.
cards.name: Free Game Notification

cards.desc:
Released new code redemption flow (in launcher and on web) that better supports linking from external sources. Enables support of retail physical disks.

**Ongoing Work:** Reduce any uses of the old redemption flow and replace with the new one.
cards.name: Code Redemption Improvements

cards.desc: Better ability to group multiple products on the storefront; including DLC, editions, and other add-ons.
cards.name: Collections and Bundles

cards.desc: Improved clarity and UI on how to use Offline Mode.
cards.name: Offline Mode Functionality

cards.desc: Released pre-load functionality to 3rd party games on the store.
cards.name: Enable Pre-loading

cards.desc: Added regional pricing for countries and territories that have previously used the US prices and refunded the difference to customers from those countries that have purchased games in the store prior to the change.
cards.name: Regional Pricing

cards.desc: We're adding an algorithmically-driven trending category to the store.
cards.name: Storefront - Trending

cards.desc: Add support for automatically refunding the difference in price for purchases that happen a short time before an offer goes on sale.
cards.name: Price Protection

cards.desc: We're expanding the store's options for displaying and discovering add-on content for games with significant amounts of add-ons
cards.name: Add-on Discovery

cards.desc: Enable the ability to buy games with various direct carrier billing providers.
cards.name: Direct Carrier Billing

cards.desc: Bundles that dynamically adjust their pricing based on whether the player already owns parts of the bundle.
cards.name: Price Adjusting Bundles

cards.desc: Add an Achievement service for titles on the Epic Games store.
cards.name: Achievements

cards.desc: Add additional local payment methods for many regions (which regions currently TBD).
cards.name: Additional Payment Methods

cards.desc: We have ongoing efforts to implement support for a variety of local currencies.
cards.name: Additional Currencies

cards.desc: General overhaul of Social Features (for example friends) to improve speed and stability of service.
cards.name: Social Overhaul

cards.desc: Enable players to follow games; giving them more control over their newsfeed.
cards.name: Newsfeed and Follow Improvements

cards.desc: Developers can enable player reviews on game pages.
cards.name: User Reviews

cards.desc: A shopping cart for the store.
cards.name: Shopping Cart

cards.desc:
Add sorting, filtering and different views to the library. Add support for moving installs and rediscovering existing installs.

**Update:** We've completed the design iteration and the first pass on all UI components.
cards.name: Library Improvements

cards.desc: Support for in-game overlay. Enables future functionality for voice, Epic friends, and in-app purchases for games.
cards.name: Epic Games Overlay
